title-group.article-title: Multifunctional behaviors of an indium tin oxide/PbLa(ZrTi)O3/indium tin oxide wafer illuminated by ultraviolet light

article-meta.aff: School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, University of Sydney, NSW, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Liyong Tong, School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, University of Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia. Email: liyong.tong@sydney.edu.au

abstract.p: This article presents multifunctional behaviors of a Pb0.97La0.03(Zr0.52Ti0.48)O3 (3/52/48) wafer subjected to ultraviolet light illumination with a focus on its photoresistive effects. When this PLZT wafer that is spurted with indium tin oxide electrodes and then polarized through thickness is illuminated by ultraviolet light, its resistance increases rather than decreases as observed in conventional photoresistors made of semiconductors. Giant negative voltage and resistance are detected when light is switched off. The bending deformation caused by the photovoltaic and converse piezoelectric effects is examined and the photoinduced electrical field strength is further investigated. The electrical fields in light on–off states are studied. Hysteresis and memristive features of the indium tin oxide/PbLa(ZrTi)O3/indium tin oxide (ITO/PLZT/ITO) sample under repetitive light on–off operations are investigated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Multifunctional behaviors of materials illuminated by light have recently attracted significant interests in areas of physics, chemistry, material science, and engineering. Barzola-Quiquia et al. (2010) measured negative resistance of ZnO single crystals. Chang et al. (2010) studied photoinduced excess carrier transport between surface states and two-dimensional electron gas channel in AlGaN/GaN structures. Calo et al. (2011) investigated electrical transport in thin films of phthalocyanine-based discotic liquid crystals in dark and on laser irradiation during long thermal cycles. These materials may be used to develop advanced electric devices. Photostrictive materials such as semiconductor, polymer, and ferroelectric ceramics can be used as actuators and sensors for wireless control and remote detection in practical applications (Lavrik et al., 2004; Poosanaas-Burke et al., 2000). Luo and Tong (2009a) discussed constitutive modeling of photostrictive materials. Wang et al. (2011) studied wireless vibration control of thin shells using photostrictive actuators.

Photovoltaic and converse piezoelectric effects of ferroelectric ceramics (e.g. PbLa(ZrTi)O3 (PLZT)) is very promising due to their high photovoltage (>1 kV/mm) and strong electromechanical coupling effect (Fridkin, 2001; Poosanaas-Burke et al., 1999). Photovoltaic effects of ferroelectric materials such as PLZT have been intensively studied (e.g. Ichiki et al., 2004, 2005; Ji et al., 2010; Poosanaas-Burke et al., 1999, 2000; Qin et al., 2009). In these studies, photovoltage and photocurrent in steady state for ferroelectric materials with different compositions and dopants were mainly examined. Nevertheless, there is no report on measurement of resistance for ferroelectric ceramics illuminated by ultraviolet (UV) light, and there are few investigations into repetitive light on–off performance and transient processes for ferroelectric materials. In addition to the photovoltage, photocurrent, temperature, and deformation, we will measure photoresistance and investigate on–off performance of an indium tin oxide (ITO)/PLZT/ITO wafer to bridge the gaps.

Many types of light-dependent resistors (LDRs) have been commercially used. When an LDR is illuminated by light with sufficiently high frequencies, photons give electrons enough energy to jump from valence to conduction bands and thus its resistance decreases. However, it is observed in our experimental testing that resistance in an ITO/PLZT/ITO device increases when illuminated by UV light. The giant negative voltage and resistance are also detected when UV light is switched off. In this article, we present multifunctional behaviors of an ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer under UV light illumination with emphasizing on the photoresistance and electrical performance for light on–off operations.

sec.title: Sample preparation and experimental setup
sec.p: The ITO/PLZT/ITO sample fabrication, measuring instruments, and experimental setup have been discussed in detail in our previous article (Luo and Tong, 2011), in which the measurements for the voltage, current, temperature, displacement, and light intensity in steady state were conducted. Here, we briefly present the PLZT sample preparation, experimental setup, and resistance measurement.

sec.title: Materials and sample preparation
sec.p: The ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer is designed to experimentally study photoresponsive behaviors of PLZT ceramics electrically poled along thickness direction and coated by ITO electrodes. It is known that Pb0.97La0.03(Zr0.52Ti0.48)O3 (PLZT 3/52/48) doped with 0.5 at.% WO3 exhibits the superb photovoltaic performance. The PLZT with this composition has been widely used to study photoresponsive performance of ferroelectric ceramics. In the present experiment, the PLZT 3/52/48 wafers spurted with transparent ITO electrodes on upper and lower surfaces were customer designed and manufactured in Boston Applied Technologies Incorporation using the conventional oxide mixing process technique. The ITO/PLZT/ITO sample is shown in Figure 1(a).

caption.p: (a) PLZT sample. (b) Experimental setup: (1) ITO/PLZT/ITO sample, (2) sensor head of Microstrain, (3) wires to electrometer, (4) light source, and (5) antivibration platform.
PLZT: PbLa(ZrTi)O3; ITO: indium tin oxide.

sec.p: When an electrical field stronger than its coercive field strength (≈2 kV/mm) is applied to the PZT or PLZT material at an elevated temperature, electric dipoles at the high temperature below the Curie Point (≈300°C) will orient along the direction of the applied electrical field, and the dipoles maintain this orientation after the removal of the electrical field and cooling down. This process is termed as poling, and the material is referred as to having been polarized. The poling efficiency depends on electrical field, temperature, and time (Chure et al., 2009; Kamel et al., 2007).

In the present sample preparation, the poling process was conducted at room temperature under an electrical field strength of 1.4 kV/mm for 2 h. For the PLZT ceramic with the same composition, Poosanaas-Burke et al. (1999) conducted a poling process in silicone oil at 2 kV/mm under 120°C for 10 min. Kamel et al. (2007) and Chure et al. (2009) showed that poling efficiency would be lower when a poling process was conducted at room temperature. Poosanaas-Burke et al. (1998) indicated that higher poling efficiency could be achieved by applying a stronger electrical field for a thinner PLZT wafer (50 µm). Therefore, the present poling efficiency is relatively low due to the lower temperature, weaker electrical field, and thicker PLZT wafer. When the polarized ITO/PLZT/PLZT wafer is illuminated by UV light, the anomalous photovoltaic field will make the ions in the unit cells shift, the domains change alignment, and then generates mechanical strain.

sec.title: Experimental setup and measurement
sec.p: The experimental setup is illustrated in Figure 1(b). The electrical circuit to measure resistance is the same as that to measure voltage. The circuits and measurement errors have been discussed in our previous article based on the user’s manual of Keithley Electrometer 6514 (Luo and Tong, 2011).

Light intensity, photovoltage, photocurrent, resistance, temperature, and displacements are measured in the present experiment. The UV light is generated by a 500-W super high-pressure mercury lamp (Ushio USH-500D: Ushio Inc.) installed in a high-power collimated beam arc lamp housing fitted with variable focus assembly (ScienceTech model: 201-1K and 201VF2: ScienceTech Inc.). In the present experiment, uniform light beam with a diameter of 40 mm illuminates cocentrically on the center portion of the PLZT sample to avoid the nontransparent wire solders.

The current, voltage, and resistance are measured using the Keithley Electrometer 6514 with the Keithley support software’s I/O Layer KIOL-850B03, IVI Driver 6485-852B04, and Excelinx-2A ELNX-852C03 (Keithley Instruments Inc.). Light intensity at 365 nm is tested using an optical power meter (Newport model: 1918-C: Newport Corp.) and a photodetector (Newport model: 918 UV-D-OD3, Newport Corp.). The instruments are installed in an antivibration platform (Herzan model 2210-01-32: Herzan LLC) and shielded cables are used to connect to a data logger via RS-232 connector.

The out-of-plane displacement is measured using Microstrain NANO-DVRT-05 (MicroStrain Inc.) with the Microstrain support software. The temperature is detected using the NI K-type thermocouple interfaced with computer via the Datalogger Ni cDAQ 9712/9211 and the LabVIEW software (National Instruments Corp.). It is noted that when a voltage of 30 V is applied to the PLZT sample using BK Precision 1761 DC power supply (B&K Precision Corp.), the recorded out-of-place displacement at the sample center is less than 50 nm.

sec.title: Multifunctional performance of an ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer exposed to UV light
sec.p: We have measured the steady-state photovoltage, photocurrent, temperature, and out-of-plane displacements of an ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer continuously exposed to UV light and studied its photostrictive effects (Luo and Tong, 2011). Here, we report on measurements of its photoresistance responses and multifunctional behaviors to UV light illumination and to the repetitive light on–off operations.

sec.title: Resistance rise and negative resistance
sec.p: When a ZnO single crystal wafer is exposed to UV light, its resistance decreases several orders when temperature is less than 200 K and reduces by 60% at temperature of 300 K (Barzola-Quiquia et al., 2010). The channel resistance in an AlGaN/GaN structure decreases from 360 to 310 Ω in steady state due to the excess charge carriers created by UV light (Chang et al., 2010). Depending on material compositions, persistent photoconductivity may last for minutes or days when light is switched off (Barzola-Quiquia et al., 2010; Chang et al., 2010; Poortere et al., 2003). However, resistance (R) of the present ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer increases from 6.6 to 29.2 GΩ in steady state when it is illuminated by UV light with an intensity of 149 mW/cm2 and a wavelength of 365 nm as illustrated in Figure 2. The resistance variation in this device exposed to UV light is opposite to that in the above materials and contradicts to that of conventional LDRs. Also, a negative resistance of 134 GΩ appears when light is switched off, which is much higher than the photoresistance in steady state. To the best of authors’ knowledge, these new phenomena observed in our experiment are not available in the existing open publications. In Figure 2, the photovoltage, photocurrent (I), and temperature (T) variations versus time in one light on–off cycle are also given.

caption.p: Photocurrent, photovoltage, resistance, and temperature variations versus time of the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer illuminated by UV light.
ITO: indium tin oxide; PLZT: PbLa(ZrTi)O3; UV: ultraviolet.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows that resistance, voltage, and current increase to their maximum values and then attain their steady values in a short time when the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer is continuously illuminated by UV light. The overshoots of electrical signals are partially attributed to the pyroelectric effects on the transient process of electrical signals (Choi et al., 2009). Figure 2 indicates that the temperature elevation is much slower than that of the electrical signals, and the electrical signals in steady state are almost unchanged with temperature rise; therefore, the contributions of the temperature increase to the photoinduced electrical field in steady state may be negligible in this ITO/PLZT/ITO device.

When UV light is switched off, resistance and voltage drop to zero and then reverse their directions. The maximum negative values (134 GΩ, 129 V) are approximately 4–5 times as large as those of photoresistance and photovoltage in steady state of the ITO/PLZT/ITO sample. It is also seen from the embedded diagram in Figure 2 that persistent photoresistance and photovoltage last for several hours. This persistence photoresistive performance is similar to that of ZnO and AlGaN/GaN materials (Barzola-Quiquia et al., 2010; Chang et al., 2010; Poortere et al., 2003).

Negative resistance and dynamic negative differential resistance have been found in metal/oxide/metal structures (Hickmott, 1962; Kim et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2008). Platinum/oxide/platinum (Pt/TiO2/Pt) nanostructures have recently attracted much attention as they have potentials to transfer markets for nonvolatile memory and new electronic devices. It is believed that Schottky barriers and coupled motions of electrons and ions play critical parts for resistive switching in this type of structure (Hickmott, 1962; Kim et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2008). The present ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer has a similar structure to that of a Pt/TiO2/Pt device. Although the present sample is not in nanoscale, its photovoltage and photocurrent in steady state are almost the same as those of the PLZT thin films (Ichiki et al., 2004, 2005; Qin et al., 2009). Therefore, the ITO/PLZT junctions in the wafer may also serve as important roles in the negative resistance effects when light is switched off. The mechanism and modeling for the resistance rise and giant negative resistance effects of the present ITO/PLZT/ITO device will be further discussed in section “Modeling, hysteresis, and memristive feature” of this article.

It is also observed in the experiment that photovoltage, photocurrent, and photoresistance are highly repeatable for UV light on–off operations. Figure 3 illustrates resistance versus time in multiple light on–off cycles. It is seen that the maximum negative resistance in the first on–off operation is slightly smaller and then increases to the constant value after two light on–off operations. A similar curve of the photovoltage to that of photoresistance has also been obtained and will be discussed in section “Hysteresis.” The large on–off ratio and stable values of photoresistance shown in Figure 3 may be useful for the multiferroic device development as these phenomena are similar to those found in other ferroic devices (Basu et al., 2008; Chen et al., 1999; Spaldin et al., 2010).

caption.p: Resistance oscillations of the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer for UV light on–off operations.
ITO: indium tin oxide; PLZT: PbLa(ZrTi)O3; UV: ultraviolet.

sec.title: Photostriction, light illumination on electrodes (+) and (−)
Photostrictive responses and electrical field distributions across the thickness
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the out-of-plane displacement at the sample center, in which the originally recorded data are plotted using the dotted line, and the solid line represents the average values in 3 s. We have shown that out-of-plane displacements in state steady denote the wafer deflections caused by superposing the photovoltaic and converse piezoelectric effects (Luo and Tong, 2011).

caption.p: The out-of-plane displacement at the center of the PLZT sample.

sec.p: It is noted that the wafer deflection becomes zero when the UV light is switched off although there is a giant negative voltage. When the voltage is applied to this ITO/PLZT/PLZT sample using a power supply, the measured out-of-plane displacements are almost zero. That is, electrical field strength in this wafer for the light off or the applied voltage case is uniform across the wafer thickness. The plate deflections generated by UV light illumination are due to the nonuniform mechanical strains that are induced by the inhomogeneous electrical field strength along thickness direction (Luo and Tong, 2009b)

In Figure 4, UV light illuminates on the electrode (+) side. By comparing the data in Figure 4 and those in our previous measurements (Luo and Tong, 2011), the wafer deflections are almost the same for both the cases of light illumination on electrodes (+) and (−).

sec.title: Electrical performance for light illumination on electrodes (+) and (−)
sec.p: In Figures 2 to 4, the measurement was conducted for UV light illumination on the ITO surface of the ITO/PLZT/ITO device marked as (+). To further study its performance, we also measured the photoinduced voltage, current, and resistance versus time of the ITO/PLZT/ITO device for light illumination on ITO electrode (−). It is observed that electrical performance in this device is almost the same for illuminating UV light on electrodes (+) and (−). Figure 5 illustrates the resistance versus time for the cases of UV light illumination on electrodes (+) and (−), which indicates that resistance variations for the two cases are almost the same.

caption.p: Resistances of the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer illuminated by UV light on electrodes (+) and (−).
ITO: indium tin oxide; PLZT: PbLa(ZrTi)O3; UV: ultraviolet.

sec.p: Similar experimental results are also obtained for the photoinduced voltages and currents for these two cases. Since the photoinduced electrical field strength is considerably less than the coercive field strength of this material (~2000 V/mm) (Poosanaas-Burke et al., 1999), this reflects that an intrinsic electrical field of the polarization in the present ITO/PLZT/ITO sample dominates motions of the photon charge carriers.

sec.title: Mechanism and modeling
sec.p: Photovoltaic effects have been found in many ferroelectric ceramics such as BaFeO3 (Basu et al., 2008; Spaldin et al., 2010), PLZT, and LiNbO3 (Fridkin, 2001; Glass et al., 1974). Their microscopic mechanisms have not been understood completely as the ferroelectric microstructures and photovoltaic effect are associated with domains of different polarization orientations, and the photoinduced multiphysics fields can be coupled. The photovoltaic effect of ferroelectrics is different from that of junction-type materials as its photovoltage in steady state is much higher than that of p–n junctions in semiconductors or Schottky barriers (Fridkin, 2001; Glass et al., 1974). This anomalous photovoltaic effect (APE) in ferroelectrics relies on polarization, impurity doping, and crystal asymmetry (Fridkin, 2001; Glass et al., 1974; Poosanaas-Burke et al., 1999). A number of models have been proposed to depict the APE in ferroelectrics (e.g. Ichiki et al., 2004, 2005; Luo and Tong, 2009b; Poosanaas-Burke et al., 1999, 2000; Qin et al., 2009).

It is well accepted that when a polarized ferroelectric ceramic is illuminated by light, it absorbs photons and creates electron and hole charge carriers; the photon charge carriers are driven by the intrinsic electrical field, and thus, high voltage is generated. This model is illustrated in Figure 6(a) and (b).

caption.p: Photovoltaic models: (a) light illumination on electrode (+), (b) light illumination on electrode (−), (c) photon charger carriers captured on domain boundary, and (d) the SEM micrograph taken from the cross section of the PLZT wafer.
SEM: scanning electron microscope; PLZT: PbLa(ZrTi)O3.

sec.p: Resistance rise in the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer may be explained using this motion model and the trapping theory of the photon charge carriers (Dimos et al., 1994) as shown in Figure 6(c). In this theory, the photon charge carriers are trapped in the domain boundary. Therefore, the enhanced intrinsic electrical field of polarization makes free electrons move more difficultly. Figure 6(d) is the scanning electron microscope (SEM) graph. Figure 6(a) and (b) is sketched on the basis of the SEM graph and the motion model of photon charge carriers, and Figure 6(c) is drafted by using the SEM graph and the trapping theory (Dimos et al., 1994). The detailed model and microscopic mechanism to describe the resistance rise and giant negative resistance need to be further studied.

As the persistence resistance lasts for several hours and negative values of resistance and voltage carry on around 1 h after UV light is switched off, the giant negative resistance and voltage are not due to overshoot effects. The current and voltage variations with time in this device for UV light repetitive on–off operation are also different from those of a capacitor in a charge–discharge process.

To study giant negative values of resistance and voltage for UV light off, we consider relationship of voltage and electrical field strength. where z denotes the thickness coordinate, E is the electrical field strength along the thickness direction, and V is the voltage.

By referring to equation (2) and Figure 2, it is seen that direction of the electrical field induced by UV light illumination in the ITO/PLZT/ITO sample is reversed after UV light is switched off. The electrical field reverse may be due to the release of the trapped photon charge carriers, their recombinations, and decay.

The energy band theory is fundamental to describing the LDRs made of semiconductors, which has been utilized to depict the photovoltage and photocurrent in steady state of PLZT materials (Poosanaas-Burke et al., 1999, 2000; Qin et al., 2009). However, it is difficult, if not impossible, to use this theory to explain the resistance rise and giant negative resistance effects in the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer exposed to UV light and for the UV light on–off operation.

It should be noted from Figure 2 that the rising of the photovoltage falls much behind that of the photocurrent when UV light illuminates on the surface of the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer, and the dropping time of the photovoltage is much slower than that of the photocurrent. The photovoltage lag to the photocurrent has also been found in a light-emitting memristor (Zakhidov et al., 2010). The time delay of voltage to current in transient processes bears memristive features (Chua, 1971; Strukov et al., 2008; Zakhidov et al., 2010). Therefore, resistance rise and negative resistance effects observed in the present experiment may be explained by using memristive concepts.

sec.title: Hysteresis
sec.p: One of the significant memristive features is a hysteresis loop of the current–voltage (I–V) curves. By using the data in Figure 2, an I–V curve can be plotted in Figure 7(a). In Figure 7(a), the data record starts from point O and UV light is turned on at point A; B1 and B2 are overshoots of photocurrent and photovoltage, respectively; point C denotes the steady state; D and E represent the maximum values of negative photocurrent and photovoltage, respectively. By referring to Figure 2, time durations for each segment are as follows: OA ∼ 30 s; AB1 < 1 s; B1B2∼ 8 s; B2C ∼ 30 s; CD1 < 1 s (light off); D1D2∼ 100 s and then it takes around 1 h for the negative voltage to become zero (D2O).

caption.p: (a) I–V curve for one full cycle, (b) I–V curves for multiple UV light on–off operations, and (c) photovoltage and photocurrent versus time in multiple on–off cycles.

sec.p: When the photocurrent and photovoltage for multiple light on–off cycles are measured, the hysteresis loops are shown in Figure 7(b) and the photovoltage and photocurrent versus time is given in Figure 7(c). Although UV light is turned on at different points of time (1), (2), (3) and (4) in Figure 7(c), the photovoltage and photocurrent are almost the same under UV light illumination.

Figure 7(b) and (c) shows that (a) the photovoltage and photocurrent in steady state for multiple light on–off cycles are almost the same; (b) when UV light is switched off, differential resistances are almost the same in multiple light on–off operations; (c) there exist obvious differences of differential resistances when UV light is turned on at different points; (d) the maximum values of photocurrents are almost the same in multiple light on–off operations and the maximum negative voltage will reach the constant value after two cycles.

sec.title: Memristive feature
sec.p: The considerable hysteresis is observed in Figure 7(a) and (b), which exhibits the memory function. A memristor is denoted by memristance M(q(t)) (Chua, 1971; Strukov et al., 2008; Zakhidov et al., 2010)
where φ(t) and q(t) are the magnetic flux and electric charge, respectively. By using the relationships of magnetic flux–voltage and electric charge–current, memristance may also be expressed as
where v(t) and i(t) are the electrical voltage and current.

There are two types of memristors, namely, electric charge–controlled memristor and magnetic flux–controlled one (Chua, 1971; Strukov et al., 2008; Zakhidov et al., 2010). The memristor developed by Hewlett-Packard (HP) Labs is the electric charge–controlled memristor, which is made of a 5nm film of TiO2 sandwiched between two Pt electrodes (Strukov et al., 2008; Zakhidov et al., 2010).

As the resistance and voltage in the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer have similar oscillations for UV light illumination and UV light on–off operations, this device works like a magnetic flux–controlled memristor. The electrical charge and magnetic flux can be calculated using

It is assumed that q(0) = 0 and φ(0) = 0; the electric charge and magnetic flux of the present ITO/PLZT/ITO sample can be calculated by using equation (5) and the data in Figure 2 and are illustrated in Figure 8(a). As the electric charge in this device increases linearly with time when UV light is continuously on, the charge measurement quickly overflows when it is measured using Keithley Electrometer 6514. When UV light is on, the resistance increases to a steady-state value, and the magnetic flux is larger than zero. Considering an enclosed surface of the PLZT wafer, magnetic strength continuously flows outside, and thus, this device works as a magnetic source under UV light illumination. When light is off, the magnetic flux decreases and the resistance decreases. When the magnetic flux becomes zero, the resistance reaches the negative peak and then the negative resistance gradually restores when the flux becomes negative. This shows that resistance of the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer could be controlled by the magnetic flux.

caption.p: Electric charge and magnetic flux of the ITO/PLZT/ITO sample exposed to UV light: (a) the calculation based on Figure 1 and (b) the calculation based on Figure 6(c).
ITO: indium tin oxide; PLZT: PbLa(ZrTi)O3; UV: ultraviolet.

sec.p: The magnetic flux curve in Figure 8(a) may be divided into four segments for one cycle of UV light on–off: (a) nonlinear increase of the magnetic flux corresponds to the resistance increase to the steady state; (b) when the resistance is in steady state, the magnetic flux increases linearly; (c) when φ > 0 and φ′ < 0, negative differential resistance appears; and (d) when φ < 0 and φ′ > 0, the negative resistance increases.

The electric charge and magnetic flux shown in Figure 8(b) are calculated by using equation (5) and the data in Figure 7(c). By comparing the data of resistance and photovoltage in Figure 2 for one UV light on–off operation and the curve of resistance in Figure 3 and that of photovoltage in Figure 7(c), it is evident that resistance of the present ITO/PLZT/ITO device exposed to UV light is coupled with its photovoltage. By referring to the second equation of equation (5), it can be seen that the nonlinear resistance of this devise is controlled by the magnetic flux. The idealized memristor response in terms of M(q(t)) is a step function for the on–off states (Chua, 1971; Strukov et al., 2008; Zakhidov et al., 2010). The present ITO/PLZT/ITO is not an ideal memristor due to existing considerable transition regions between on and off states.

As the photoresistive effects of an ITO/PLZT/ITO device are similar to photovoltages or controlled by the photoinduced magnetic flux, the influences of PLZT wafer’s size, thickness, surface quality, composition, fabricating, and poling processes on the photoresistor may be similar to the photovoltage in this type of PLZT material as investigated in the study by Poosanaas-Burke et al. (1998, 1999, 2000), which need to be further investigated. In the present experiment, photovoltage, photocurrent, and photoresistor have been measured for different light intensities and illumination locations, light illumination surfaces with electrode (+)/(−). It is found that the photoinduced behaviors depend on the light intensity and illumination area, but they are almost not influenced by the illumination location and wire solder (very small compared to illumination area).

The APE in ferroelectric ceramics has been studied over three decades, but a broad range of applications has not been achieved owing to the lower energy transfer efficiency and complex energy transformation. With the development of nanotechnology and the worldwide energy shortage, ferroelectric materials have recently become an important research area. The high power transfer efficiency of the photovoltaic effect in PLZT has been achieved by using ultrathin PLZT films with the ITO electrode (Chen et al., 2011; Qin et al., 2009). The findings on ferroelectric ceramics responses to light illumination may be useful to develop multiferroics, light emitting diode devices, and light memristors (Basu et al., 2008; Choi et al., 2009; Zakhidov et al., 2010).

Although a strong light intensity of 149 mW/cm2 was used in the present experiment, the APE can be created in the ITO/PLZT thin film by the weak light illumination with an intensity of 0.2 mW/cm2 (Qin et al., 2009). Resistance in the present ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer is very high, but it can be significantly reduced in nanoscale PLZT films.

PLZT ceramics have been explored to be used as actuators and sensors for remote and wireless control operations in microelectro/optomechanical systems and intelligent structures by utilizing their photovoltaic and converse piezoelectric effects (Luo and Tong, 2009b; Poosanaas-Burke et al., 2000; Shih and Tzou, 2000; Wang et al., 2011). The present investigations into multifunctional behaviors for the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer show that it may also be used as a generator, nonlinear resistor, and control component due to the strong reverse electric field, peculiar resistive performance, and highly repeatable features. The PLZT materials would be promising in the context of developing a new type of LDRs, multiferroic devices, and light memristors.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We presented multifunctional performance of the ITO/PLZT/ITO wafer polarized along thickness direction illuminated by UV light. The novel findings are its resistance rise for the continuous UV light illumination and giant negative resistance after UV light off, which are quite different from light responses observed in conventional LDRs and other materials. Their mechanisms are discussed by using the motion model of photon charge carriers (dominated by the intrinsic field of polarization), the trapping theory (trapped on the domain boundary), and memristive concepts.

Based on the measured data of the electrical signals, temperature variations, and mechanical deformations, the electrical fields in the PLZT wafer polarized along thickness direction for the UV light on and off states are analyzed. The motion model of photon charge carriers and the theoretical predictions for electrical strength distributions across thickness of the PLZT wafer for UV light on and off states are evidently supported by the present experiment.

The giant reverse voltage after switching off UV light was also detected in the present experiment and the wafer deflection was further studied, which showed that PLZT ceramics can be used as a generator, an actuator, and a sensor. The present investigation into multifunctional performance of PLZT materials indicates potentials of developing a new type of LDRs, light multiferroic devices, and memristors.
